cleaned_text: There has been a lot of controversy surrounding the link between CDC vaccines and autism. Some people believe that vaccines can cause autism, while others argue that there is no scientific evidence to support this claim. In this blog post, we will explore the facts and myths surrounding CDC vaccines and autism. The Facts - CDC vaccines do not cause autism. There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that vaccines cause autism. - The CDC recommends that all children receive vaccines to protect them from serious diseases. - Vaccines are safe and effective. They have been rigorously tested and have been shown to be safe for children and adults. - Vaccines do not overload a child's immune system. Children are exposed to many germs every day, and their immune systems are designed to handle this exposure. The Myths - Some people believe that thimerosal, a preservative used in some vaccines, can cause autism. However, thimerosal has been removed from most vaccines, and studies have shown that it does not cause autism. - Some people believe that the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps, and rubella, can cause autism. However, numerous studies have shown that there is no link between the MMR vaccine and autism. - Some people believe that vaccines can overload a child's immune system and cause autism. However, this is not true. Children are exposed to many germs every day, and their immune systems are designed to handle this exposure. Conclusion The link between CDC vaccines and autism is a controversial topic, but the scientific evidence is clear: vaccines do not cause autism. Vaccines are safe and effective, and they protect children from serious diseases.
